706104f-a.folder: Ocean Avenue & Voorhies Avenue, Brooklyn, NY
706104f-a.text:
(1)  Ocean Ave., at the S.E. corner of Voorhies Ave., showing the Sheepshead Bay M.E. Church, erected in 1840. John Y, McKane a member of this church and Superintendent of the Sunday School for over 20 years was born in Ireland in 1841 and settled in Gravesend in 1842, where he married the daughter of Capt. Cornelius B. Nostrand in 1865. The building in this view was erected in 1869.
December 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)
The same, at a later date.
August 1929.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

706103f-a.folder: Ocean Avenue & Voorhies Avenue, Brooklyn, NY
706103f-a.text:
Ocean Ave., at the S.E. corner of Voorhies Ave., showing the Sheepshead
Bay Methodist Episcopal Church.
July 6, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

706105f-a.folder: Ocean Avenue & Voorhies Avenue, Brooklyn, NY
706105f-a.text:
(1)
3041 Ocean Ave., east side, near the N.E. corner of Voorhies Ave. A view of Memorial Hall and Bill Brown Post of the American Legion, named in honor of the first American to fall in battle. (Former Comptroller Cunningham was a member of this Post.)
July 8, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
Same, slightly different angle.
July 6, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

706106f-a.folder: Ocean Avenue & Voorhies Avenue, Brooklyn, NY
706106f-a.text:
3106-3150 Ocean Ave., west side, between Voorhies and Emmons Ave. No. 3150 is Bobs Restaurant, at left foreground.
July 13, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

706702f-a.folder: Voorhies Lane & Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, NY
706702f-a.text: Coney Island JJockey Club Inc., of New York City, was bounded on the south by Voorhees Lane, on the eest by Ocean Ave., on the north by Ave. V and on the east by Brown Street. This club, founded in 1879, held its first races on the Prospect Park Fair Grounds. I 1880 the construction of the Sheepshead Bay Race Track was completed, and it was opened on June 19, 1880. William K. Vanderbilt was president in 1904. TNis track was one mile in circumference, but it was extended in 1884 to 1 and 18 miles, and in 1886, a mile track was constructed inside the old. The oval track was between East 23rd Street and Nostrand Ave., and Aves. W and 2.  Mrs Harriman a daughter of one Gerritsen owned this track which comprised about 125 acres, that was purchased by Max Natanson, Joseph P, Day, and Charles F. Noyes for .S2,400,O00 on April 1, 1915. They in turn, cut it into lots and sold them at auction in August and September 1923. Parts of the track in (1937) including some of the stables may yet be seen. The grounds are still referred to as the Harkness Estate. This view shows the stands and straight-away. The foundations of the stands are still visible north of Jerome Ave. (1937)
